chapter.title: &ooo; Impress, Base, Draw, and Math
chapter.para: Besides &ooo; Writer and &ooo; Calc, &ooo; also includes the modules Impress, Base, Draw, and Math. With these you can create presentations, design databases, draw up graphics and diagrams, and create mathematical formulas.

sect1.title: Using Presentations with Impress
sect1.para: Use &ooo; Impress to create presentations for screen display or printing, such as slide shows or transparencies. If you have used other presentation software, you can move comfortably to Impress, which works very similarly to other presentation software.
Impress can open and save Microsoft Powerpoint presentations. This means you can exchange presentations with Powerpoint users, as long as you save your presentations in Powerpoint format.

sect2.title: Creating a Presentation
sect2.para: There are three ways to create a new Impress document:

formalpara.title: From Scratch
formalpara.para: To create a document from scratch, click File New Presentation and a new empty Impress document is created.

formalpara.title: Wizard
formalpara.para: To use a standard format and predefined elements for your documents use a wizard. Click File Wizards Presentation... and follow the steps.

formalpara.title: Templates
formalpara.para: To use a template, click File New Templates and Documents and choose one file from the Presentation Backgrounds folder. A new document based on the style of your selected template is created.

sect2.para: The following procedure describes how to create a presentation by using the wizard. Proceed as follows:

step.para: Start &ooo;.
Select File Wizards Presentation...
Choose From template and select Presentation Backgrounds from the pop-up menu to set your preferred background and click Next.
Select a slide design. You can choose from a variety of backgrounds and ready-made presentations. To create your own design, select <Original> from the list.
Select an output medium. The output medium is the form the final presentation will take, such an overhead sheet, paper, or a screen slide show, among other choices.
Select Preview for a thumbnail showing your choices. If all options are set according to your wishes, click Next.
If you want to use effects for slide transitions, select the Effect you want to use and specify the Speed.
Either use the default presentation type or choose Automatic to specify the amount of time each page displays and the length of the pause between presentations.
If all options are set according to your wishes, click Create.

sect2.para: The presentation opens, ready for editing.

sect2.title: Using Master Pages
sect2.para: Master pages give your presentation a consistent look by defining the way each slide looks, what fonts are used, and other graphical elements. Impress uses two types of master pages:

listitem.para: Contains elements that appear on all slides. For example, you might want your company logo to appear in the same place on every slide. The slide master also determines the text formatting style for the heading and outline of every slide that uses that master page, as well as any information you want to appear in a header or footer.
Determines the formatting and appearance of the notes in your presentation.

sect3.title: Creating a Slide Master
sect3.para: Impress comes with a collection of preformatted master pages. Eventually, most users will want to customize their presentations by creating their own slide masters.

step.para: Start Impress.
Create a new empty presentation.
Click View Master Slide Master .
This opens the current slide master in Master View.
Right-click the left-hand panel, then click New Master.
Edit the slide master until it has the desired look.
Click Close Master View or View Normal to return to Normal View.

tip.para: When you have created all of the slide masters you want to use in your presentations, you can save them in an Impress template. Then, any time you want to create presentations that use those slide masters, open a new presentation with your template.

sect3.title: Applying a Slide Master
sect3.para: Slide masters can be applied to selected slides or to all slides in the presentation.

step.para: Open your presentation.
(Optional) If you want to apply the slide master to multiple slides, but not to all slides. Select the slides that you want to use that slide master applied to.
To select multiple slides, pressCtrl in the Slides Pane while clicking on the slides you want to use.
In the Tasks Pane, open the Master Pages and click the master page you want to apply. The slide master is applied to the corresponding page(s).
If you do not see the Task Pane, click View Task Pane .

sect1.title: Using Databases with Base
sect1.para: &ooo; includes a database module: Base. Use Base to design a database to store many different kinds of information, from a simple address book or recipe file to a sophisticated document management system.

Tables, forms, queries, and reports can be created manually or by using convenient wizards. For example, the Table Wizard contains a number of common fields for business and personal use. Databases created in Base can be used as data sources, such as when creating form letters.
It is beyond the scope of this document to detail database design with Base. More information can be found at the sources listed in .

sect2.title: Creating a Database Using Predefined Options
sect2.para: Base comes with several predefined database fields to help you create a database. A wizard guides you through the steps to create a new database. The steps in this section are specific to creating an address book using predefined fields, but it should be easy to follow them to use the predefined fields for any of the built-in database options.
The process for creating a database can be broken into several subprocesses:

step.para: Start &libo; Base.
Select Create a new database. Proceed with Next.

Click Yes, register the database for me to make your database information available to other &ooo; modules and select the check boxes to Open the database for editing and Create tables using the table wizard. Then click Finish.
Browse to the directory where you want to save the database, specify a name for the database, then click OK.

sect3.title: Setting Up the Database Table
sect3.para: After you have created the database, if you have selected the Create tables using the table wizard check box, the table wizard opens. If you have not, click the Use Wizard to Create Table... link in the Tasks area. Next, define the fields you want to use in your database table.

step.para: In the Table Wizard, click Personal.
The Sample tables list changes to show the predefined tables for personal use. If you had clicked Business, the list would contain predefined business tables.
In the Sample tables list, click Addresses.
The available fields for the predefined address book appear in the Available fields menu.
In the Available fields menu, click the fields you want to use in your address book.
You can select one item at a time, or you can shift-click multiple items to select them.
Click the single arrow icon to move the selected items to the Selected fields menu.
To move all available fields to the Selected fields menu, click the double right-arrow.
Use the and keys to adjust the order of the selected fields, then click Next.
The fields appear in the table and forms in the order in which they are listed.
Make sure each of the fields is defined correctly.
You can change the field name, type, maximum characters and whether it is a required field. For this example, leave the settings as they are, then click Next.
Click Create a primary key, click Automatically add a primary key, click Auto value, then click Next.

sect3.title: Creating a Form
sect3.para: Next, create the form to use when entering data into your address book.

step.para: In the Form Wizard, click the double right-arrow icon to move all available fields to the Fields in the form list, then click Next.
Select Add Subform if you want to add a subform, then click Next.
For this example, accept the default selections.
Select how you want to arrange your form, then click Next.
Select The form is to display all data and leave all of the check boxes empty, then click Next.
Apply a style and field border, then click Next.
For this example, accept the default selections.
Name the form, select the Modify the form option, then click Finish.

sect3.title: Modifying the Form
sect3.para: After the form has been defined, you can modify the appearance of the form to suit your preferences.

step.para: Close the form that opened when you finished the previous step.
In the main window for your database, right-click the form you want to modify (there should be only one option), then click Edit.
Arrange the fields on the form by dragging them to their new locations.
For example, move the First Name field so it appears to the right of the Last Name field, and then adjust the locations of the other fields to suit your preference.
When you have finished modifying the form, save it and close it.

sect3.title: What’s Next?
sect3.para: After you have created your database tables and forms, you are ready to enter your data. You can also design queries and reports to help sort and display the data.
Refer to &ooo; online help and other sources listed in for additional information about Base.

sect1.title: Creating Graphics with Draw
sect1.para: Use &ooo; Draw to create graphics and diagrams. You can save your drawings in today’s most common formats and import them into any application that lets you import graphics, including the other &ooo; modules. You can also create Flash versions of your drawings.

step.para: Start &libo; Draw.
Use the toolbar at the bottom of the window to create a graphic.
Save the graphic.

sect1.para: To embed an existing Draw graphic into an &ooo; document, select Insert Object OLE Object . Select Create from file and click Search to navigate to the Draw file to insert. If you insert a file as OLE object, you can easily edit the object later by double-clicking it.

procedure.title: Opening Draw From Other &ooo; Modules
procedure.para: One particularly useful feature of Draw is the ability to open it from other &ooo; modules so you can create a drawing that is automatically imported into your document.

step.para: From an &ooo; module (for example, from Writer), click Insert Object OLE Object &ooo; 3.x Drawing OK .
This opens Draw.
Create your drawing.
Click in your document, outside the Draw frame.
The drawing is automatically inserted into your document.

sect1.title: Creating Mathematical Formulas with Math
sect1.para: It is usually difficult to include complex mathematical formulas in your documents. To make this task easier, the &ooo; Math equation editor lets you create formulas using operators, functions, and formatting assistants. You can then save those forumlas as an object that can be imported into other documents. Math functions can be inserted into other &ooo; documents like any other graphic object.

note.title: Math is For Creating Mathematical Formulas
note.para: Math is not a calculator. The functions it creates are graphical objects. Even if they are imported into Calc, these functions cannot be evaluated.

sect1.para: To create a formula proceed as follows:

step.para: Start &libo; Math.
Click File New Formula . The formula window opens.
Enter your formula in the lower part of the window. For example, the binomial theorem in &ooo; Math syntax is:
The result is displayed in the upper part of the window.
Use the Formula Elements window or right-click the lower part of the window to insert other terms. If you need symbols, use Tools Catalog... to, for example, insert Greek or other special characters.
Save your document.

sect1.para: It is possible to include your formula in Writer, for example. To do so, proceed as follows:

step.para: Create a new Writer document or open an already existing one.
Select Insert Object OLE Object... in the main menu. The Insert OLE Object window appears.
Select Create from file.
Click Search... to locate your formular. If needed, you can activate Link to file.
Confirm with OK and your formular is inserted at the current cursor position.
